title: Treasurer says QE summit a 'distraction'
text:
On Thursday the Reserve Bank of Australia released a detailed analysis of how a first stage quantitative easing measure known as repurchase agreements could be better handled so as to avoid bank failures.

The timing of the research paper is interesting given the focus on the potential introduction of quantitative easing measures by the Reserve Bank and when and how the central bank will go about this given record low interest rates.

In the research paper called "Emergency Liquidity Injections" the central bank's Nicholas Garvin argues that greater flexibility around the duration and size of repurchase agreements has huge benefits in times of financial crisis.

Mr Garvin uses a pretty dire scenario to test this, describing a situation where there is a "system-wide withdrawal of funding liquidity that forces banks to sell securities, causing securities price depression to the point that banks cannot survive the withdrawal."

He argues that in this situation repurchase agreements, which are effectively short term loans by the central bank to commercial banks at virtually no cost to provide temporary liquidity, should be tailored much better.

"If banks are allowed to choose the proportion of their liquidity deficit that is funded by the capital injection, an immediate implication is that no banks would be insolvent," Mr Garvin notes.

He also suggests that lending duration should be adaptable.

"Lending should be long term so that repayments are due after liquidity conditions improve. Otherwise, the repayments can cause further liquidity distress, compromising the policy objectives."

"This need to be more lenient to banks when they take more liquidity risk, and the consequential lack of credible deterrence, occurs because the policy does not require banks to commit future assets.

"The authority only receives compensation (i.e. securities) for its liquidity provision at the height of the crisis, when banks have little to compensate without failing."

His model demonstrates that lending to banks via repo can curb fire selling of relatively illiquid securities that are accepted as collateral. This, he said would mitigate falling prices in securities and counteracts the effects of fire sale.
description: Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has hit back at calls from ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott for a summit on low interest rates and quantitative easing, saying it's a "distraction from the failure of big banks".
